Commands.Comment:
This Script is not used here, but is an Incomplete Script to Move Up/Down Ladders.
Essentially, it turns On Clipping on the Player, allowing them to Move through Collision.
Turns off the Controls and Moves the Player Up/Down.
Then turn Clipping back Off and Re-enables the Controls.
Saves the Unique ID of the NPC - Used in the Annotation within the UI Text Box Loaded Script

Commands.Body: Welcome to the <u>Archive</u>.

Here you can read up on how to set up a
<u><fontcolor[#FFFF0000]>Message Box</fontcolor></u> or display <u><fontcolor[#FFFF0000]>Dialogue Options</fontcolor></u>.
As well as the various Text Formatters, Control Sequences and Replacements.

A full list of those can be found on the
<u><fontcolor[#FF00CFFF]>RPGA</fontcolor></u> Wiki Page for <u>TextEscapeCodes</u>.
Interact with the bookshelves or holotables for more details.

Commands.Comment: This Script Informs you about the Message Box and Dialogue User Interface.
Saves the ID of the Player for use in the Annotation Script in the Text Box Script.

Commands.Body: Section 1: Database - User Interfaces: "Message Box" and "Dialogue Options".

Commands.Comment:
The Dialogue Option here lets you pick which Topic to Read.
The Message Box or the Dialogue.

Commands.Body: Message Box - Documentation Section - 0

The Message Box is the Template UI used for the "Display Static Message" Command.
Found in the Database - User Interface. Using the User Interface Type - "Message Box".
It is primarily made out of Four Elements:
Header Element - Represents the Speaker
Body Element - The Main Text
Portrait Element - The set Portrait
Prompt Element - The Displayed Prompt when the Message is Concluded.

These can be found by scrolling down past the Scripts and Transitions.
When set, this is where the Information in the "Display Static Message" Command will be Displayed.

The Header and Body Element is a "Text" Replacement and the Portrait is a "Picture" Replacement.
Whereas the Prompt is the Visual Displayed when the Message is ready to proceed.
For now, focus on Adding a "Text" Element and a "Pane" Element to the UI, by clicking the Green + Icon.
From there you can Adjust the Various Settings, such as Height and Width of the Text Area. Font, Font Size, Color, Drop Shadow, Character Delay and so on.
Once the needed Elements have been made, you put them into their respective section. Without that being set, they are just a static visual on the screen.

Finally there are Two more elements to the Message Box. First the Checkbox for "Collate Messages". This makes it so when the following Message is using the same Message Box Template, it does not Reload the Background Element, without there could be a small flashing in and out as it Reloads.

And Lastly, we have the "Pagination Strategy", this one is how the Message Behaves when the Text within the "Display Static Message" Command is longer than the Height of the Message Box Template.

There are Three Options:
"Clear Text", "Retain Line" and "Retain Paragraph".

For the Messages primarly used here, we have it set to Clear Text, where should the Text be longer than the Set Height the Full Remaining Text will be Displayed. For these examples, we will change the Message Template used within the following Messages.

So first off, Clear Text. As stated, this is the one we decided to use for the majority of the Text Messages here, we we mostly try to keep the Text within the boundaries. But should the Text be longer, once it reaches the end of the Template Height, it will require an addition Confirm Press to Continue.

So for the Retain Line Option, rather than Clearing all the Text above and starting over from the Top, it will clear proceed down one line, adding more Text as it goes along, needing several more Confirm Presses.

Finally we have the Retain Paragraph Option. This one, similar to Retain Line, scrolls down as it is proceeding, except, rather than proceeding Line by Line, goes by Paragraph by Paragraph, obviously the longer the set Paragraph, the more Text will be Displayed per Pressed Confirm.
These are the Basics for the Message Box UI, feel free to try out the various Options to find what suits your own Game. Best of Luck.
Dialogue Options - Documentation Section - 0.1

The Dialogue Type is the Template used for the "Display Dialogue Options" Command. 
Composed of Two Key Elements.
Background Element and Options Element.

Followed by Three Options-
Shrink Horizontally
Shrink Vertically
Pause Gameplay
First, the important part is the "Options Element" the Linked "List" is where the Options Added in the "Display Dialogue Options" Command is Displayed at.

Secondly, the "Background Element" is a "Pane", a Background png.
With a Pane linked to the Background Elements you can check whether or not the Image Shrinks both Horizontally and Vertically to the Size of the Options List.

Doing so the Background Limits itself to the List, so to get the best result, one would alter the Panes Position Margins. It will look awkward within the UI Preview, so is a matter of testing to find the best result.
Yes I believe I understand it, sort of.
Fantastic, Feel free to Interact with the Holotable once more if you wish to repeat this conversation.
Fare thee well!
No, not really...
Huh?<pause> Oh, uh...<pause> Well speak to the Holotable again, and we can, uh, try this again.
Till Next time.

Commands.Comment:
This Conditional makes it so you can only Interact with this Entity while the Player is Facing North.
If North, the Script will Continue as normal, else it will Run the "Exit Script" Command and close the Script.
The "Move Entity" Command here Changes the Sprite used for this Entity.

Within the Script, the Saved ID alternates between the Player and the Spawned Entity Definition.
So when the Player is Speaking, the Saved ID is for the Player.
Placing the "Save Entity Unique ID" Command above the "Display Static Message"
Then when it is the NPCs turn the "Save Entity Unique ID" is placed above it again
but this time with the ID of that Entity.

Commands.Body:
- Basic Annotations -<pause>
Annotations is a Text or Sprite added onto an Entity, such as an exclamation mark above their heads.
You might have seen it a few times here.
So lets go over the basic one we are using here.

Commands.Comment:
This Switch Prevents the "Entity Defitnition -> Annotations Interactions" which is used to display the "?" above the players head
when standing near an Interactable object, from activating while the current Script is Running.

Spawns the Entity Definition "Summoned NPC". Storing its ID in a Local Variable.
That Local Variable is in turn used to save that ID to the Annotation Script within the Text Box.

Commands.Body: Hello.
Uh, hey.
For this Message Box, we have the Annotation Script set within the UIs Loaded and Unloaded script page. These will be discussed in more details in a later section.
But for now, the Loaded Script is the Commands that run when an UI is Loaded, and Unloaded is, as the name states, when the UI is Unloaded.
For this Script, in the Loaded Section we have added an Annotation that places a small speech bubble above the speakers head.
The Actor it targets is based on an Unique ID Saved to a Global Variable, which we save from within the Entity Script from which the message is called from.
Global Variable? Unique ID? What are those?
I am glad you asked, an Unique ID is one of the most important aspects of RPGA.
It saves the ID of an Entity, an Actor, Items or Skills etc. With an Unique ID, which is saved as a string into a Variable, you can control many different things and manipulate them as you wish.
But we are getting ahead of ourselves. And you might have noticed that the small chat bubble changes which Actor it targeted.
Yeah, I guess I did!
Within the Entity Script, we update which Unique ID to the one we intend to be the one speaking.
So when the NPC (Me) is speaking we are using the ID of this spawned NPC. And when the Hero (You) is speaking we are using the ID for the Party Slot 0. (The first Hero Slot in the Party).
So the annotation we have is called directly from the UI, based on the Unique ID which set within the script. The script this conversation is using.
Then in the Unloaded Script for the Message UI, we Clear the Annotation so it doesn't stick around unwanted.
Is all this clear so far?
Yes I believe I understand it, sort of.
Fantastic, Feel free to Interact with the Holotable once more if you wish to repeat this conversation.
Fare thee well!
No, not really...
Huh?<pause> Oh, uh...<pause> Well speak to the Holotable again, and we can, uh, try this again.
Till Next time.

Commands.Comment:
Finally, it Removes the Spawned Entity Definition.
Turns off the Switch so the "?" Annotation will appear.
And Changes the Sprite back of this Entity.

This Entity uses Two Different Script Pages to Display the Entities Sprite Change.
With the Second Page being Set to Automatic, So when this First Page is Interacted with
it Turns On a Local Switch which Activates the Second Page. Which in turn, Turns the Switch Off when Finished.
Further, the Conditionals Set, makes it so you can only Interact with this Entity while the Player is Facing "North"

Commands.Body: "User Interfaces - General Overview"
The User Interfaces in RPGA is setup in the "Database - User Interfaces"

Here you set the Type of UI:
<u>Dialogue</u> - Template for "Display Dialogue Options" Command
<u>Menu</u> - Main/Equip/Item Menu, etc
<u>Message Box</u> - Template for "Display Static Message" Command
<u>Overlay</u> - An Overlay, to display texts, gauges etc.
<u>Shop</u> - Template for the "Open Shop" Command

Commands.Comment: This Script Informs you about Text Formatters.
Saves the ID of the Player for use in the Annotation Script in the Text Box Script.

Commands.Body:
A Text Formatter alters how a specific line of text is Displayed.
This is done with a <<<<> tag and a <<<</> closing tag.
For example. Adding a <<<Infront of the text makes everything between it and the<<< Bold.
Or such as <<<<fontcolor[#FF00CFFF]><fontcolor[#FF00CFFF]>Makes the Text Blue</fontcolor><<<</fontcolor>.
Or even <<<<cd[100]><cd[100]>which alters the set Character Delay</cd><<<</cd>. That is however bypassed should you Skip the Character Delay, more on that later.

Commands.Comment: This Script Informs you about Text Control Sequences.
Saves the ID of the Player for use in the Annotation Script in the Text Box Script.

Commands.Body:
A Control Sequence alters the interaction with the text.
Same as the Formatter it uses a <<<<> tag aswell as a <<<</> closing tag when needed.
For instance. Adding a <<<<wait[1500]><continue><pause> infront, makes the Message <wait[1500]>wait 1500 milliseconds before it continues.

Other tags include a <<<<pause> and a <<<<continue> tag. Both of these were used in the previous Message.<pause>
If you hit Confirm to skip the Character Delay at the beginning, you notice the Delay continues after the <<<<wait> tag.
This was done combining with: <<<<wait[1500]><<<<continue><<<<pause>.

The <<<<continue> tag emulates the Confirm Virtual Key. If placed at the end of the message, it will automaticaly close when finished. Where as the <<<<pause> requires an additional Confirm to continue. When combined with the <<<<wait> tag, such as above, the text first waits 1500 seconds, then it emulates a confirm which triggers the pause.

Commands.Comment: This Script Informs you about Text Replacements.
Saves the ID of the Player for use in the Annotation Script in the Text Box Script.

Commands.Body:
A Text Replacement, replaces the text with a Value from the Database.
These are commonly used within Menus or Overlays.

For instance, the <<<<<<fps> tag shows the FPS the game is running at, seen here: <fps>. Or your Characters name <<<<<<party[0]> "<party[0]>", which shows the Name of the Character in the 0 Slot of the Database.

These have quite a few options, ranging from showing the name of an Item from the Database <<<<<<item[0]> to showing an Icon inside the Message Box <<<<<<icon[0]>. For Icons you can even have a <<<<<<icon[0,32]> which would show the first Icon in the Spritesheet at 32 pixel size.

But one very important one would be the <<<<<<globalvar[0]> or <<<<<<localvar[0]>. Or the shorter version <<<<<<gv[0]>/<<<<<<lv[0]>. These show the Values of that Variable in the Text, the same goes for <<<<<<gs[0]>/<<<<<<ls[0]> which shows the Value for the Switches.

The <<<<<<gv[0]> and <<<<<<gs[0]> will show the Result from the Global Variable/Switches, where as <<<<<<lv[0]> and <<<<<<ls[0]> will show the Local Variable/Switches. These can be very useful when Testing, to see if a Variable or a Switch behaves as expected, as well as many other uses.

Commands.Comment: This Script Explains how the Dialogue Skip Script is built.
Saves the ID of the Player for use in the Annotation Script in the Text Box Script.

Commands.Body: Here we will explain how to setup the Script to skip the Character Delay for Messages, and have them be Displayed Instantly.
It is built into a Virtual Key, using the same Keybinding as the Confirm key, as well as within Message Box UI.
When the Message Box is Loaded, it activates a Switch, used within the Virtual Key, that in this project is placed in the "Database - Virtual Key - Slot 007", called "DisplayAllText".
This Switch makes it so that the Virtual Key does not run without a message being present. This is to prevent the Virtual Key to activate when it is not wanted.

Within the VK Script, it utilizes the Script Command "<fontcolor[#FFFF0000]>Display All Messages</fontcolor>". This Command makes all Present Text bypass the Character Delay, now, on its own, being set to the same VK as the Confirm, means both will Initiate at the same time, causing the Message to Instantly proceed when pressed.

This is where we used a Variable to prevent that, inside the VK Script, we also have a "Change Variable" Command, which sets its Value to <<<<<<pause> then "Waits" 100 millisecond and removes the <<<<<<pause> Value.

This Value is used within a Secondary Text Element within the Message Box UI, which has the following Text <<<<<<gv[1]>. So that when we uses the DisplayAllText Virtual Key, it adds a <<<<pause> tag to the Message. Preventing it from instantly proceeding when using the VK.
And as the Virtual Key Script also removes the <<<<<<pause> tag, it is not present when you do not skip the Dialogue, otherwise one would need to hit Confirm twice to end the Message.
